The atom-efficient production of glycerol carbonate via transesterification between dimethyl carbonate and glycerol over fluorinated Al2O3-ZrO2 solid solution catalysts with suitable acidic-basic property Dengfeng Wang Project administration Supervision Writing − review & editing, Project administration, Supervision Dong Bai Data curation, Investigation Jie Xiong Data curation, Formal analysis Zheng Chen Supervision, Funding acquisition Xueying Zhao Software, Investigation Hongwei Wu Writing − review & editing ⁎ Jianfeng Shan Funding acquisition, Investigation ⁎ Shuwei Wei Resources, Visualization, Supervision, Writing − review & editing ⁎ Xuelan Zhang Conceptualization, Methodology, Data curation, Writing − original draft, Investigation ⁎ College of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Materials Science, Zaozhuang University, Zaozhuang 277160, PR China College of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Materials Science, Zaozhuang University Zaozhuang 277160 PR China College of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Materials Science, Zaozhuang University, Zaozhuang, 277160, P.R. China ⁎ Corresponding authors. A series of Al2O3-ZrO2-nF solid solution catalysts (n was the F: Al atomic ratios) with Al: Zr molar ratio of 0.2, was fabricated by addition of varied amounts of (AlF6)3- into the ZrO2 via a co-precipitation method. To our delight, the acidic-basic properties of Al2O3-ZrO2-nF can be tuned by the change of n. Then, the role of acidic-basic sites was investigated for the glycerol carbonate (GLC) production from glycerol and dimethyl carbonate (DMC). Despite that the more basic samples exhibited higher reactivities compared to that of the more acidic ones, the cooperative effect between the acidic-basic pairs can enhance the catalyst activity strongly. So, the catalyst with F/Al= 1.0 can realize the quantitative and selective transformation of glycerol to GLC applying DMC/glycerol of 1:1 ratio with a GLC yield of 91.2%, owing to its appropriate acidic-basic property. Furthermore, the uniform solid solution structure can prevent the generation of free Al or F species, assuring the catalytic material an excellent stability. More importantly, several green parameters including process mass intensity, environmental factor and atom utilization were calculated to confirm the environmental and economic compatibility of the GLC synthesis over the model catalyst. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Glycerol Transesterification Glycerol carbonate ZrO2-based catalyst Fluorine content Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction In recent decades, the fast-growing consumption of fossil resources has not only given rise to their depletion, but also led to many environmental problems. Especially, the CO2 concentration in the atmosphere has continuously risen year by year, mainly responsible for the global warming [1,2]. Herein, the conversion of biomass into renewable fuels is generally accepted as a promising strategy, offering new, green energy resources without CO2 emissions. In this sense, the biodiesel industry, involving the transesterification of seed oils with methanol, has been rapidly developed [3]. However, a huge amount of crude glycerol with low-price is also co-formed, undoubtedly lowering the biodiesel business competitiveness to some degree. Therefore, it is an enormous significance to explore effective catalytic means for the glycerol conversion into valuable chemicals [4–6]. Over the past decades, several interesting techniques such as reduction into 1,2-propanediol [7], selective oxidation into dihydroxyacetone [8,9], dehydration into lactic acid [10], glycerol conversion into fuel additives [11], and carboxylation into glycerol carbonate (GLC) [12] have been proposed. Thanks to its outstanding merits of high flash point, high boiling point, low toxicity, and biodegradability, GLC has been applied broadly as surfactants, polar solvents, gas separation membranes and wetting agents for cosmetic clays [13]. In addition, it can also be used as a multi-functional and high-reactive starting material for the polymer formation [14]. It is famous that GLC could be created between reaction of glycerol with diverse types of the carbonate group, such as phosgene [15], CO [16], and CO2 [12]. However, the industrial application of the above-mentioned methodologies has been constrained dramatically by their corresponding disadvantages like application of high-toxic raw materials, easy explosion, low glycerol conversion and requirement of harsh reaction conditions [17]. Different from these approaches, the reaction between glycerol and urea can be performed following the atom-economic rule with a glycerol/urea molar ratio of 1:1. Unfortunately, a great deal of toxic and corrosive NH3 is co-generated and must be removed timely under vacuum. Otherwise, the GLC yield would be extremely low [18]. Besides, the industrial utilization of this process is hampered to some extent by its inferior GLC selectivity because of the co-manufacture of many by-products [19]. Alternatively, a greener and simpler synthetic technique would be the transesterification between glycerol and organic carbonates, which can be carried out below 150 oC without release of poisonous chemicals [20]. Of diverse carbonate candidates, dimethyl carbonate (DMC) is the first choice due to its facile separation of co-product of methanol, which can decrease the entire process cost significantly, thanks to the low boiling point of methanol [20,21]. Homogeneous catalysts (NaOH, Na2CO3) exhibited high reactivities for the GLC synthesis, but they suffered from poor recovery and environment pollution greatly [22]. Herein, numerous heterogeneous catalysts such as single oxides [22], mixed oxides [23], supported catalysts [24], hydrotalcites [25], calcined hydrotalcites [26,27], silica-based catalysts [28], and aluminates [29] have been estimated for the transesterification of glycerol and DMC in the prior documents. Despite that many meaningful results have been obtained, the synthesis of GLC is often conducted with DMC/glycerol molar ratios between 3 and 5. Obviously, this is not in accordance with the principle of “atom economy”, since there would be excess DMC molecules in the reaction system, creating much cost and high inconvenience for the following GLC purification. Therefore, we are still lacking of a novel catalyst fulfilling the efficient GLC production with a yield over 90% using an equimolar DMC/glycerol ratio, under mild and solvent-free conditions. On the other hand, the importance of acidic-basic pairs for the transesterification is widely accepted by a lot of researchers, but there still exists a controversy that which center gives a major contribution for the high yield of GLC. For example, Liu et al. observed that the catalytic ability of transition metal doping Mg-Al mixed oxides originated from their surface basic sites [27]. Similarly, G. Parameswaram et al. proposed that the high reactivity of MgO-CeO2 samples was ascribed to the existence of strong basic sites [30]. However, Parmila et al. demonstrated that the acidic nature of Ti-SBA-15 was the decisive factor for the GLC synthesis [28]. Besides, some other reports considered that the activities of samples depended on the synergistic effect of acidic-basic sites [31,32]. In our previous experiment, we merely evaluated the relationship between basic properties and catalytic performances of CaO-ZrO2, but lacking of systematic study of influence of catalyst acidic nature on the GLC synthesis [33]. So, the role of acidic-basic pairs for the GLC manufacture should be better understood and this issue is still widely open for a further investigation. In this work, a series of fluorinated Al2O3-ZrO2 catalysts with a large range of F content were fabricated utilizing Na3AlF6 as the F source. Precise insights into the nature of acidic-basic pairs for the GLC synthesis were achieved due to their varied acidic-basic properties along with different catalytic performances. To our delight, we found that this catalytic system could provide an efficient GLC production under mild and atom-economic conditions with a high GLC yield of 91.2%. At the same time, the overall investigation concerning green chemistry metrics proved that this catalytic process was significantly promising for its economic and environmentally benign advantages. Finally, the developed catalyst can be reused up to four cycles without a notable loss of activity due to its stable and uniform solid solution structure. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Al2O3-ZrO2-nF catalysts with the same Al3+/Zr4+ atomic ratio of 0.2, but varying F/Al molar ratios (n = 0, 0.5, 1, 2), were obtained by a co-precipitation procedure followed by the reflux treatment [21]. In the present work, Al(NO3)3·9 H2O or a mixture of Al(NO3)3·9 H2O and Na3AlF6 was employed as the source of aluminum, while fluorine was only from Na3AlF6. Taking Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F catalyst as an example to illustrate the detailed preparation process: 8.58 g Zr(NO3)4·5 H2O, 1.25 g Al(NO3)3·9 H2O together with 0.14 g Na3AlF6 were dissolved into 100 mL deionized water. Another 100 mL aqueous solution containing 5.76 g (NH4)2CO3 was prepared as the precipitant. Then, these two solutions were simultaneously added dropwise into a beaker with vigorous stirring at 50 oC to generate a white precipitate. The slurry was continuously stirred for another 2 h at 50 oC, and then moved into a flask, refluxed in deionized water at 80 oC for 6 h. After cooled to room temperature, the suspension liquid was filtered and rinsed with deionized water for several times until the pH of filtrate became neutral. Finally, the solid sample was dried at 100 oC for 8 h and calcined at 600 oC for 6 h under N2 atmosphere. For pure Al2O3 and ZrO2, the synthesis method was similar to the aforementioned procedure, but only Al(NO3)3·9 H2O or Zr(NO3)4·5 H2O was selected to prepare the corresponding oxide, respectively. Additionally, AlF3 and ZrF4 were purchased from commercial reagent companies without any purification. For comparison, F-containing ZrO2 catalyst without Al was prepared by the impregnation method. Briefly, 1.0 g grinded pristine ZrO2 obtained by the co-precipitation process was put into a 20 mL aqueous solution having 0.1 g NaF. After stirred for 2 h, the impregnated catalytic material (denoted as F-ZrO2) was treated at 50 oC in vacuo to remove water overnight. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of samples were recorded on an X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku MiniFlex) using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) with a step of 4o/min in a 2θ range of 5–80o. Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) was employed to determine the chemical compositions of catalysts using the Thermo iCAP 6300 instrument. In addition, fluorine content in the catalysts was analyzed by the ion-selective electrode method. Textural properties of catalysts were studied by nitrogen physisorption experiments at − 196 oC on a Micromeritics ASAP-2020 instrument. Before analysis, the samples were preheated at 300 oC for 6 h under vacuum to purify the sample surface. The BET isotherm and BJH model were employed to determine the specific area and pore volume, respectively. The Raman spectra were acquired on a Horiba-Jobin-Yvon spectrometer using a He-Ne laser light source excited by the 532 nm laser. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) image of catalysts was obtained on a Hitachi S4800 apparatus performing at an accelerating voltage of 20.00 kv. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) of catalysts was conducted on a JEOL JEM-2100 device at 200 kV. Acidic-basic properties of samples were measured by the temperature programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) and carbon dioxide (CO2-TPD) using NH3 and CO2 as probe molecules, respectively. Prior the test, 100 mg of catalysts were pretreated in Ar at 300 oC for 2 h to clean their surfaces. Next, the samples were treated in the flow of NH3/CO2 (40 mL·min-1) for 3 h and then were flushed with Ar flow (40 mL·min-1) to eliminate physical adsorbed molecules. Finally, the TPD tests were started from 30 to 600 oC with a speed of 10 oC /min under Ar flow (40 mL·min-1), and the desorbed probe molecules were monitored by an AMETEK mass spectrometer. Their peak areas were quantitatively calculated by injection of pure NH3 and CO2 pulses preliminarily, respectively. 2.3 Catalytic reaction The catalytic experiments for the solventless reaction of glycerol and DMC were evaluated in a 50 mL stainless-steel autoclave with a magnetic stirrer. In a typical test, 0.1 g freshly prepared catalysts, 40 mmol glycerol and 40 mmol DMC were successively put into the reactor. Afterwards, the reaction mixture was stirred constantly at 110 oC for 1.5 h, and quickly cooled to room temperature by a cold-water bath to stop the reaction. The solid catalyst was separated from the reaction products by filtration, washed with methanol several times and dried at 80 oC over night for the next run. The liquid products were analyzed by a GC equipped with a HP-5 capillary column and a flame ionization detector. The column was initially set as 80 oC for 3 min, then increased to 240 oC with a heating rate of 30 oC/min, and kept this temperature for another 3 min. The FID and injection temperatures were fixed at 250 oC and 260 oC, respectively. The products quantification was calculated on the basis of the response factors of the reactants and products. The reactant conversion (X reactant), products selectivity (S product) and products yield (Y product) were defined as Eqs. (1)−(3), respectively: (1) X reactant = Initial reactant mol − Unreacted reactant ( mol ) Inicial reactant ( mol ) × 100 % (2) S product = Product ( mol ) Inicial reactant ( mol ) − Unreacted reactant ( mol ) × 100 % (3) Y product = X reactant × S product × 100 % (4) TOF = Inicial glycerol mol × X glycerol × M glycerol ( g mol − 1 ) m catalyst g × Reaction time ( h ) × 100 The turnover frequency (TOF) was determined by the formula 4, where M glycerol , m catalyst are molecular weight of glycerol and catalyst amount, respectively. Here, the catalyst amount instead of the number of active sites because that the catalytic activities of samples were not related to Al, F, Zr or O atoms, but to the acidic-basic pairs. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural and structural properties of the catalytic samples Chemical analysis demonstrated that the Al/Zr atomic ratio in Al2O3-ZrO2-nF samples were very close to 0.2 (see Table 1). Additionally, the F/Al atomic ratio in fluorinated Al2O3-ZrO2 was found to be close to the nominal values, except for Al2O3-ZrO2-2 F. According to previous documents, these results were relevant to the stability of (AlF6)3- species in solution [34,35]. Due to the ionic equilibrium between (AlF6)3- and (AlF4)- in aqueous solution containing aluminum-sodium fluoride mixtures, only (AlF6)3- can be precipitated and incorporated into solid structure under alkaline conditions. In this work, during procedure of co-precipitation, (AlF6)3- was formed constantly to meet the Le-Chatelier’s principle. As too large amount of (AlF6)3- species was added to fabricate catalyst of Al2O3-ZrO2-2 F, some (AlF4)- species, which could not enter the solid structure, might still exist in the mother solution, giving rise to the lower F content for Al2O3-ZrO2-2 F compared to its corresponding nominal value. Fig. 1(a) displays the XRD patterns of all the catalytic samples. For the prepared Al2O3 sample, characteristic diffraction peaks of γ-Al2O3 appeared at 2θ = 31.9o, 37.6o, 45.8o, and 66.8o (γ-Al2O3, JCPDS 29–0063). As to the ZrO2 obtained via the co-precipitation method, it was mainly in the monoclinic ZrO2 phase (m-ZrO2, JCPDS 37–1484) mixed with some in the tetragonal ZrO2 phase (t-ZrO2, JCPDS 79–1769) [36]. After the introduction of guest atoms of Al3+ and F-, Al2O3-ZrO2-nF samples only remained t-ZrO2 peaks, implying the transformation of m-ZrO2 to t-ZrO2. Besides, no diffraction lines ascribed to Al2O3, fluorides such as AlF3 and ZrF4 emerged. More importantly, the t-ZrO2 peak (101 plane) at around 30o gradually moved to the lower angle with the increase of F/Al atomic ratio. We compared the lattice values of this plane for each Al2O3-ZrO2-nF sample in Fig. 1(b). Obviously, the spacing parameters increased monotonically with the raise of n due to the relatively higher ionic radius of F- (1.4 Å) in comparison of that of Zr4+ (0.84 Å) [37] . Furthermore, the d 101 value of Al2O3-ZrO2-0 F was lower than that of pure ZrO2 (0.29453 nm) because of the lowest ionic radius of Al3+ (0.54 Å) among the three kinds of ions. Thereby, it can be said that Al and F species had been incorporated into t-ZrO2 matrix, resulting in the generation of a solid solution structure [37,38]. The low-angle XRD patterns of ZrO2 and Al2O3-ZrO2-nF catalysts are shown in Fig. 1(c). An obvious peak can be found at about 1o for pure sample of ZrO2, pointing out that it possessed a relatively uniform mesoporous structure [21,39]. However, introduction of guest species into ZrO2 caused the decline of intensity of this peak. In particular, catalyst of Al2O3-ZrO2-2 F showed the lowest intensity, suggesting that it exhibited a poorly ordered mesoporous structure compared to other samples. This might give an adverse effect on their BET surface areas and exposure of active sites, in turn, unfavorable for their catalytic activities. To better illustrate the mesoporous structure of ZrO2 and Al2O3-ZrO2-nF catalysts, they were further analyzed by N2 absorption/desorption characterization. Fig. 2 shows their N2 absorption-desorption isotherms and BJH pore size distribution profiles. Clearly, all the samples had type IV isotherms and exhibited meso-pores with a pore volume of 0.23–0.37 cm3 g-1 (see Table 1) [40]. Meanwhile, the isotherms hysteresis loops varied remarkably with the change of the F content. Larger hysteresis loops were found in ZrO2 and Al2O3-ZrO2-0 F samples, implying the formation of well-defined pore and larger BET surface areas. Addition of F gave rise to the decline of intensity of the hysteresis loops. Especially, only a diminutive H3-shaped hysteresis loop emerged when the value of n was 2, indication of its poorly defined mesoporous structure, which was well consistent with the results of low-angle XRD. Moreover, pore size distribution profiles displayed that the range of pore diameter broadened as the increase of F content, also verifying the conclusion above-mentioned. The BET surface area (S BET) of catalytic materials is given in Table 1. It was easy to find that the order of S BET was inverse with that of value of n. As a result, Al2O3-ZrO2-2 F exhibited the lowest S BET of 145 m2 g-1. The solid solution structure of the Al2O3-ZrO2-nF samples was further affirmed by Raman spectroscopy with a 532 nm laser. For comparison, Al2O3, AlF3 and ZrF4 were examined together and the spectra are shown in Fig. 3. Clearly, pristine ZrO2 showed the characteristic bands associated with m-ZrO2 phase at approximate 331, 380, 538 and 560 cm-1. Meanwhile, the leftover peaks centered at about 269, 316, 470 and 645 cm-1 could be assigned to t-ZrO2 phase. Interestingly, upon adding foreign Al3+ or F- species, the resulted catalytic materials of Al2O3-ZrO2-nF only presented characteristic peaks of t-ZrO2 phase, confirming that doping guest atoms can stabilize the tetragonal structure of ZrO2. We also noted that the peaks at 269 and 645 cm-1 continuously shifted to lower wavenumbers with the increase of n. Furthermore, the Raman shifts belonged to Al2O3, AlF3 or ZrF4 were not observed for Al2O3-ZrO2-nF. All these facts proved again that the guest species had entered into t-ZrO2 lattice, producing a solid solution structure. The SEM images of the ZrO2 and Al2O3-ZrO2-nF catalysts are shown in Fig. 4. It can be seen that all the catalytic samples mainly consisted of irregular sphere-like particles. As to catalysts of ZrO2 and Al2O3-ZrO2-0 F, their crystal sizes were detected between 10 and 20 nm. Upon introduction of F-, some fragments appeared and the spherical structure became vaguer slightly as the increase of n value. Besides, compared to the fluorine-free materials, the dispersion of particles was poorer over fluorine-containing samples and the particles agglomerated severely for the catalyst of Al2O3-ZrO2-2 F. Meanwhile, the elemental maps of Zr, Al, F and O for the sample of Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F are given in Fig. 4(f), in which a relatively uniform distribution of these elements can be observed. This also revealed that F- had been incorporated the catalyst structure successfully. To have more accurate information at the nanoscale, both the ZrO2 and Al2O3-ZrO2-nF catalysts were further investigated by TEM (see Fig. 5). It can be seen that ZrO2 and Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F were mainly composed of spherical nanoparticles with a diameter range of 10–20 nm, fully in line with their SEM images in Fig. 4. Furthermore, the nanoparticles present in both materials were interconnected. As a result, it can be expected that there might be some slit pore differences between the nanocrystals and micrometer-scale morphology. Indeed, two kinds of crystal (m-ZrO2 and t-ZrO2) structures and crystal lattice spacings were apparently observed for ZrO2 sample, and the m-ZrO2 was in predominant. As to the catalyst of Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F, the measured lattice parameters were around 2.95 Å and 2.73 Å, relevant to the (101) and (110) plane of t-ZrO2, respectively [41]. Similar experimental results were also detected for another three fluorinated Al2O3-ZrO2 catalysts (see Fig. S1). These phenomena well agreed with the XRD and Raman experimental results and further affirmed that adding Al3+ and F- could bring about the conversion of the m-ZrO2 to t-ZrO2 phase. 3.2 Surface acidic-basic property The NH3-TPD profiles of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 6(a). It can be seen that all the TPD curves consist of several NH3 desorption peaks, suggesting a variety of acidic sites with different strength available on the surface of catalytic samples. According to the desorption temperatures, the acidic sites could be split into three groups, which were corresponding to weak acidic sites (below 200 oC), medium acidic sites (between 200 and 400 oC) and strong acidic sites (over 400 oC), respectively [42]. Moreover, the desorption curves of the weak and acidic sites can be further divided into four peaks, named as α 1 peak (below 150 oC), α 2 peak (between 150 oC and 200 oC), β 1 peak (between 200 oC and 300 oC) and β 2 peak (between 300 oC and 400 oC), respectively. Meanwhile, the surface acidity of catalysts is shown in Table 1, and the acidic sites distribution on these catalysts is given in Table S1. Evidently, bare ZrO2 exhibited the lowest acidity of 57.2 μmol g-1 among these catalysts. Furthermore, its weak acidic sites contribution to the total acidic sites was about 68%, whereas that of the strong acidic sites was only 10.8%. Interestingly, addition of Al3+ into ZrO2 gave a great impact on the distribution of acidic sites of catalytic samples. In comparison with the catalyst of ZrO2, the medium and strong acidic sites of the Al-containing samples became more intense at the expense of the weak counterparts. Especially, the proportion of medium and strong acidic sites over Al2O3-ZrO2-0 F was 83.5%, which was approximate 2.5 times that of Al-free material (ZrO2). More importantly, its acidity was improved obviously due to that Al2O3 was more acidic than ZrO2 [43]. Upon incorporation of (AlF6)3- into it, a consecutive decline of acidic density can be seen with the rise of value of n. These results can be explained as follows: on the one hand, addition of foreign atoms into ZrO2 gave rise to an evident reduction in the surface area (see Table 1), which was negative for the exposure of acidic sites. On the other hand, introduction of Al3+ can enhance the catalyst acidity. Therefore, the beneficial effect derived from Al3+ surpassed the harmful effect caused by the decline of surface area on Al2O3-ZrO2-nF acidic properties, judging from that they had greater numbers of acidic sites than that of ZrO2. However, as to the fluorine-modified Al2O3-ZrO2 catalysts (Al2O3-ZrO2-0.5 F, Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F and Al2O3-ZrO2-2 F), considering that they contained similar content of Al, so, the passive effect of surface area on their total acidic densities was in a dominant position. Thus, their surface acidities decreased as the following order: Al2O3-ZrO2-0 F> Al2O3-ZrO2-0.5 F> Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F> Al2O3-ZrO2-2 F> ZrO2. Fig. 6(b) illustrates the CO2-TPD profiles of ZrO2 and Al2O3-ZrO2-nF samples. It could be observed that all the materials contained three kinds of basic sites. The desorption peaks in the range of 50–200 oC, 200–400 oC and 400–600 oC were ascribed to weak, medium and strong basic sites, respectively [42]. In case of ZrO2 and Al2O3-ZrO2-0 F catalysts, the above-mentioned basic sites were corresponding to OH- groups, metal-oxygen pairs and unsaturated O2- atoms, respectively [19,21,39]. After introduction of (AlF6)3- into the catalytic samples, the metal-fluorine pairs and unsaturated F- atoms were also produced, contributing to medium and strong basic sites, separately [44]. At the same time, the desorption profiles of fluorinated samples assigned to medium basic sites could be further divided into two peaks (δ 1 and δ 2 peak). Furthermore, with the increase of F content, the desorption peak of strong basic sites gradually shifted to higher temperature, indicating that the basic strength of catalysts was promoted with the rise of n. Besides, the number of the basic sites was analyzed, and the results are demonstrated in Table1 and Table S1. Compared to that of pristine ZrO2, the contribution of medium and strong basic sites presented an obvious increase for sample of Al2O3-ZrO2-0 F. However, a little enhancement was found for the total number of basic sites. That’s to say, Al3+ alone hardly increased the basicity of ZrO2 enormously, for Al2O3 was usually regarded as a more acidic oxide [22,45]. The highly acidic character of Al2O3 was also proved by the NH3-TPD/CO2-TPD profiles in Fig. S2 (a), which clearly showed that Al2O3 had a broad NH3 desorption peak over a wide temperature range of 95–600 oC. In contrast, it only showed a small CO2 desorption peak. As a result, the acidity and basicity of the prepared Al2O3 were 111.5 μmol g-1 and 38.3 μmol g-1, respectively (see Table 1). In theory, low surface area led to the decrease of the exposed basic sites. Nevertheless, doping (AlF6)3- into ZrO2 can increase the basicity of the resulted catalysts remarkably, in spite of its adverse influence on their surface areas. A plausible explanation for such phenomenon could be suggested as follows: it was well known that the creation of metal-fluorine pairs hardly reduced the number of metal-oxygen pairs, because that the metal content in pairs (M-O and M-F) only occupied very little proportion of the entire metal content in mixed metal oxide catalysts [46]. Thereby, increase of F content brought about the increase of metal-fluorine pairs, in turn promoting the medium basic sites amount consistently. In addition, the strong basic sites associated with coordinatively unsaturated O2- and F- were mainly generated by the cleavage of metal-oxygen and metal-fluorine pairs. Previous studies revealed that with the increase of F additive, more and more unsaturated O2- and F- would be present on the catalyst surface, undoubtedly resulting in the enhancement of amounts of basic sites [35,44,45]. In light of the similar amounts of weak basic site for the F-containing samples, so, their total basicity elevated continuously as the rise of value of n. Together with aforementioned results, it can be concluded that the beneficial effect caused by the rise of F prevailed its disadvantage influence on the basicity of the Al2O3-ZrO2-nF catalysts. The higher the F loading, the greater number of the basic sites. Consequently, Al2O3-ZrO2-2 F exhibited the highest basic density among all the catalytic materials. To summarize, our NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD experiments demonstrated that the incorporation of Al3+ and (AlF6)3- into ZrO2 not only promoted the acidity of the prepared Al2O3-ZrO2-nF catalysts, but also boosted their basicity distinctly. Moreover, F content also had a considerable influence on the acidic-basic sites distribution and strength of the catalysts, therefore might affect their catalytic performances towards the GLC synthesis enormously. 4 Catalytic performance 4.1 DMC transesterification with glycerol In order to clarify the reaction system of the transesterification between DMC and glycerol in the present work, GC-MS was applied to identify the chemical components in the liquid reaction products. Based on the experimental results, the possible reaction network is depicted in Scheme 1. As expected, the main reaction path is the transesterification of DMC with glycerol, producing the target product of GLC (Box A). A secondary possible product of diglycerol tri-carbonate from reaction of DMC and glycerol, which was reported by other researchers, was not detected [14,47]. Instead, an undesired-product of glycerol decarbonate (GDC) was identified due to the further transesterification between the hydroxyl group of GLC and another DMC molecule (Box B). In addition to these two compounds, another by-product of glycidol (GD), formed via the decarboxylation of GLC, was also found in this contribution. 4.2 Catalytic performance of samples for the GLC synthesis Initially, all the catalytic samples were evaluated for the solventless GLC synthesis with a glycerol/DMC molar ratio of 1:2 at 110 oC. The test results in terms of glycerol conversion, GLC selectivity and GLC yield are displayed in Table 2. Without a catalyst, the reaction can take place to some extent, but the glycerol conversion was only 20.5%. When ZrO2 was selected as the catalyst, the catalytic result was still far from satisfactory (Entry 2). Under the same reaction conditions, Al2O3 exhibited a lower glycerol conversion of 32.5% than that of ZrO2 (Entry 3). In comparison with ZrO2, Al2O3-ZrO2-0 F gave a marginal increase of glycerol conversion (52.9%), revealing that merely addition of Al3+ into ZrO2 hardly promoted this reaction (Entry 4). In contrast, all the F-containing catalytic materials afforded higher glycerol conversions than that of Al2O3-ZrO2-0 F, implying the positive effect of F on this reaction. Importantly, the glycerol conversion gradually increased as the rise of F content and reached the maximum value of 100% when n was 1.0 (Entry 6). However, further increase of F content led to an evident decrease of catalyst activity due to that Al2O3-ZrO2-2 F gave an inferior glycerol conversion of 93.7% (Entry 7). Different from this trend, the GLC selectivity decreased consecutively as the increase of n. As a consequence, Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F possessed the highest GLC yield of 95.2% of all the catalytic materials. Considering the distinct reactivities of F-containing catalysts, the reaction conditions were further optimized to realize the sustainability of GLC production by reducing the overdose of DMC. Theoretically, decline of DMC/glycerol ratio was passive for the glycerol conversion owing to the equilibrium restriction. Therefore, an evident reduction of glycerol conversion was noted from 79.8% to 68.6% as the DMC/glycerol ratio decreased from 2:1–1:1 over catalytic material of Al2O3-ZrO2-0.5 F (Entries 5, 11). Unlike this sample, both Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F and Al2O3-ZrO2-2 F still kept high activities (Entries 12, 13). And only a negligible decrease (1.6%−6.6%) was found over them under the identical conditions. Thus, the catalytic abilities of Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F and Al2O3-ZrO2-2 F were well-tolerated towards the reduction of DMC amount. Importantly, it should be mentioned that a high selectivity of GLC (92.7%) was achieved over Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F (Entry 12), whereas a more notable decrease in selectivity from 93.1% to 88.4% was observed over catalyst of Al2O3-ZrO2-2 F (Entry 13). As a result, we can obtain an excellent GLC yield of 91.2% using Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F, surpassing the activities of other samples greatly. Herein, Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F was chosen as the model catalyst to further optimize the reaction parameters with an equimolar DMC/glycerol ratio under solvent-less condition. 4.3 Influence of the reaction condition on the GLC synthesis The influence of reaction temperature on the GLC synthesis is illustrated in Fig. 7(a). Apparently, the catalytic performance was highly affected by the reaction temperature. The glycerol conversion improved consistently with the increase of temperature from 90 oC to 110 oC. However, the yield of GLC reached its peak value of 91.2% at 110 oC. Above this temperature, a drop of GLC yield could be observed, which might be attributed to the formation of GDC from GLC. Meanwhile, the decomposition of GLC into GD also aggravated gradually at a relatively high temperature. Thus, the optimum temperature for the GLC synthesis should be 110 oC. The catalytic performance of Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F was also be influenced markedly by the reaction time (Fig. 7(b)). Notably, the glycerol conversion promoted monotonically within 1.5 h. Further increase of reaction time only gave rise to a slight increase of glycerol conversion but an evident decrease of GLC yield. Consequently, the highest GLC yield of 91.2% could be obtained at 1.5 h. Therefore, the suitable reaction time was 1.5 h. The effect of catalyst amount on the reaction is shown in Fig. 7(c). It can be observed that the glycerol conversion improved gradually from 68.2% to 98.4% when the catalyst amount increased from 0.02 g to 0.1 g. However, both the glycerol conversion and GLC yield reduced slightly as the catalyst amount further increased to 0.14 g. This is mainly because of the enhanced resistance of the mass transfer in the tri-phase system of solid catalyst-glycerol-DMC, which was also reported in other documents [32,48]. Meanwhile, the consumption of GLC in further reaction such as manufacture of GDC and GD might be another cause for the decline of the GLC yield. In summary, under optimum reaction conditions, both glycerol conversion and GLC yield can surpass 90% with an equimolar glycerol/DMC ratio over Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F sample. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time for achieving the efficient synthesis of GLC via atom economic transesterification of DMC and glycerol in lab scale under mild reaction conditions without solvent. 4.4 Effect of acidic-basic sites in transesterification of DMC with glycerol It was generally acknowledged that GLC production can be boosted by the both acidic and basic sites [21,22,28,31,32]. In principle, acidic sites are beneficial for the DMC adsorption via linking with carbonyl oxygen atom of DMC, whereas basic sites facilitate the activation of glycerol molecules with release of H δ+ from its hydroxyl group, providing glycerol anions (see Scheme 2). Next, nucleophilic reaction between glycerol anions and absorbed DMC molecules takes place, generating monoglyceride intermediates. Similar to above-mentioned process, cyclic rearrangement of the monoglyceride intermediate is further catalyzed over the acidic-basic sites to give the target product of GLC, accompanying methanol as the side-product [31,32]. According to the discussion aforementioned, incorporation of Al3+ and (AlF6)3- into ZrO2 can increase the catalyst acidity and basicity, respectively. This point was strongly supported by the fact that compared to bare ZrO2, Al2O3-ZrO2-nF samples had enhanced NH3 uptakes, whereas F containing samples possessed more desorbed CO2. Thus, it was reasonable to speculate that the improved activity of Al2O3-ZrO2-nF samples could be assigned to the increased acidity and basicity by the addition of Al3+ and F- ions. After a careful search, no obvious relation was established between catalytic abilities and the acidic-basic property, because that the most active sample of Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F did not possess the highest acidic or basic strength among these catalysts (see Fig. 6). In order to better understand the function of acidic-basic sites and their collaborative effect on the transesterification reaction, we further investigate the correlation between acidity, basicity, or a unifying parameter of acidity-basicity (acidity/basicity ratio, named as A/B) of the examined samples and their catalytic performances. As shown in Fig. 8, the more basic catalytic materials with A/B value below 1.0 (Al2O3-ZrO2-0.5 F, Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F, Al2O3-ZrO2-2 F and F-ZrO2 catalysts) displayed relatively high reactivities. Conversely, when the parameter of A/B was above 1.0, the more acidic catalysts such as Al2O3, ZrO2 and Al2O3-ZrO2-0.5 F exhibited relatively inferior glycerol conversions. In other words, activation of glycerol on basic sites seemed to be more critical than the absorption of DMC on acidic sites for the synthesis of GLC. However, it should be noted that the highest glycerol conversion was obtained over catalyst of Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F, although it had a higher A/B value than that of Al2O3-ZrO2-2 F. This suggested that the catalytic abilities of catalysts were not merely dependent on the surface basicity. Both the concentration of acidic and basic sites could improve the reaction of glycerol and DMC. Thanks to its suitable A/B value among all the catalytic materials, Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F demonstrated the highest catalytic ability. In case of samples with highly acidic character such as Al2O3, ZrO2 and Al2O3-ZrO2-0 F, their inferior activities might be ascribed to that they did not possess enough amounts of basic sites to activate glycerol. Similarly, although the basicity of Al2O3-ZrO2-0.5 F was improved to some degree, the glycerol conversion was still lower than that acquired on Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F sample. This point indicated that the basic density of Al2O3-ZrO2-0.5 F was still inadequate for realizing the efficient synthesis of GLC. Unlike these three materials, Al2O3-ZrO2-2 F exhibited relatively more base sites, but the acidic sites were poor availably on its surface. Accordingly, it gave a lower reactivity, probably owing to the lack of acidic sites that could simultaneously activate DMC molecules. As a result, the driving force towards the GLC manufacture was still insufficient for this sample. Additionally, F-ZrO2 catalyst without Al was also prepared using impregnation method to affirm the importance of cooperation of acidic-basic pairs for the efficient synthesis of GLC. Clearly, sample of F-ZrO2 was a typical basic catalyst with a large and broad CO2-desorbed peak in the range of 100–600 oC (see Fig. S2(b)) and its basicity could be 135.6 μmolg-1. In contrast, there was only a small peak at around 150 oC in its NH3-TPD profile, implying poor availability of acidic sites on its surface (32.7 μmolg-1). Not surprisingly, F-ZrO2 catalyst only afforded a lower glycerol conversion of 72.2% than that of Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F, owing to weak collaboration of acidic and basic sites (see Table 2, Entry 14). In addition, to better understand the correlation between glycerol conversion and acidic/basic property (acidity/basicity ratio determined by NH3/CO2-TPD, named as A/B) and support the mechanism shown in Scheme 2, we illustrated the catalytic activity at 20 min when the reaction was at beginning in Fig. 9. It shows the highest glycerol conversion for a balanced A/B material (Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F), whereas lower glycerol conversion were found for the more acidic or basic materials.Thus, it could be stated that the outstanding catalytic ability of Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F probably originated from its optimum synergistic effect of acidic and basic sites. A well balance of acidic and basic sites was extremely decisive for the excellent synthesis of GLC. Too high or too low A/B value was disadvantageous to achieve a high glycerol conversion. The key to the transesterification of glycerol and DMC was to precisely regulate the acid-base properties of the catalysts. Furthermore, such acidic-basic synergistic catalytic mechanism for the GLC manufacture has been also emphasized and recognized widely by other studies. Pradhan et al. concluded that the acidic proton of primary hydroxyl group of glycerol was abstracted by Lewis basic site of CaO with simultaneous activation of carbonyl carbon of DMC by Lewis acidic site of TiO2 of CaO/TiO2 catalyst [32]. More recently, She et al. reported that the Lewis basic sites derived from -M-OH group of sodium montmorillonite facilitated the generation of glyceroxide anions, whereas the Lewis acidic sites originated from MII (MIII) atoms were beneficial to the carbonyl activation of DMC [49]. Chang et al. also proposed that the deprotonation of glycerol (on basic sites) were likely more important than the activation of DMC (on acidic sites) for the transesterification of glycerol and DMC over MgO@ZIF-8 catalysts. More importantly, the enhanced activity of MgO@ZIF-8 suggests a synergistic effect between MgO and ZIF-8, which was attributed to the collaboration between the basic and acidic sites on the surface [31]. 4.5 Reusability of catalyst of Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F Addition to the catalytic ability, the stability of the catalyst is another vital character for its potential industrial application. Therefore, the reusability of Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F was further estimated under the optimized reaction conditions. After each reaction, the used Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F was recycled by filtration, washed using methanol for three times, dried at 80 oC for 3 h. Then, it was directly reused for the next run. Fig. 7(d) shows that no evident declines were demonstrated for glycerol conversion, GLC yield and GLC selectivity after Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F was reused four times, indicative of its outstandingly high stability. Moreover, Fig. S3 displays the comparison of the XRD patterns between the fresh and the recycled Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F catalyst (Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F-fourth). Clearly, the reused sample still maintained the original t-ZrO2-like structure. At the same time, Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F-fourth also possessed a high BET surface area of 162 m2 g-1, given by N2 absorption/desorption technique. Furthermore, CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD characterizations revealed that the acidic and basic densities of Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F-fourth were 77.1 μmol g-1 and 101.8 μmol g-1, respectively. More interestingly, afore-mentioned systematic characterization displayed that the prepared sample of Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F had a solid solution structure, where both F and Al species were well incorporated into t-ZrO2 matrix. Considering that the acidity and basicity of Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F were mostly associated with these two guests, so, the formation of solid solution can inhibit the leaching of active sites. Meanwhile, the solid structure also prevented the contamination of basic sites by the H2O and CO2 in the atmosphere to some degree, which was no doubt good for the catalyst to keep the high catalytic ability. 4.6 Activity comparison of Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F with other catalysts in previous documents Various solid catalysts have been explored for the synthesis of GLC. Of them, perovskite-like ternary oxides such as SrTiO3-200 and YNbO4-200 were tested with an equimolar DMC/glycerol ratio, but the glycerol conversions were only 77.7% and 82.5%, respectively (Entries 2, 3 in Table 3) [50]. Mg-Ca mixed oxide (Mg1.2Ca0.8O2), a typical base catalyst, could give about 70% glycerol conversion with DMC to glycerol ratio of 1 (Entry 4) [51]. The major shortcoming related to Ca-based sample was the poor catalyst stability, which might be due to the interaction between active CaO phase and glycerol, creating a calcium glycerol species into liquid phase [32,52,53]. Indeed, a severe catalyst deactivation was also observed for this Ca-based sample, leading to about 10% decline after reused four times with DMC/glycerol ratio of 2 (Entry 5). Except these three catalysts, other reference catalytic samples were usually utilized with DMC/glycerol ratio of 3–5. As a consequence, it was difficult to directly compare our Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F catalyst with previously reported materials. Thereby, we prepared and compared three representative reported samples under our reaction conditions. Basic catalytic sample of KF/γ-Al2O3, which was fabricated by wet impregnation approach, provided a relatively high glycerol conversion of 91.4% at the first cycle (Entry 6). Unfortunately, a serious catalyst deactivation was noticed and the glycerol conversion declined to 80.8% at the fifth cycle [54]. According to previous documents, this behavior was mainly attributed to the leaching of potassium species from the catalyst [55,56]. Unlike KF/γ-Al2O3, solid acid catalyst of Ti-SBA-15 showed a relatively high stability for the GLC synthesis, but the glycerol conversion was only 78.3% (Entry 7) [28]. MgO-loaded ZIF-8 catalyst (MgO@ZIF-8), which was regarded as a bifunctional acidic-basic catalyst [31], could not realize the atom-efficient synthesis of GLC, for the glycerol conversion was only 80.5% (Entry 8). The superior and distinctive reactivity of our Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F compared with other samples was more convincing in terms of TOF (intrinsic activity). Obviously, the TOFs of the catalysts were in the sequence of Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F> KF/γ-Al2O3 > MgO@ZIF-8 > Ti-SBA-15 > Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 > SrTiO3-200 > YNbO4-200 with DMC to glycerol ratio of 1. Hence, it was evidenced that Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F was a highly active and robust solid catalyst for the green, atom-efficient synthesis of GLC in lab under moderate reaction conditions. 5 Green metrics of transesterification of glycerol with DMC Generally speaking, green chemistry aims to fulfil the efficient utilization of raw feedstocks without the employment of toxic regents and solvents during the production of chemical products. Beside this, the waste formed during the entire process should be treated properly, avoiding environmental pollution [57,58]. In this work, we selected three kinds of green parameters including environmental factor (E-factor), process mass intensity (PMI), and atom utilization (AU) to evaluate the transesterification of glycerol with DMC, and the values of the three parameters over different catalysts are shown in Table 4. First, E-factor was determined by the ratio between total amounts of waste to the target product (see formula 5) [59]. Obviously, this parameter would be increased with the increase amount of waste created during the reaction. Therefore, a lower value of E-factor was more favorable for environment and its value was preferably between 0 and 1 [60]. (5) E − factor = Mass of waste ( g ) Mass of products ( g ) In this work, methanol was an easily recoverable solvent. Similarly, the by-products of GD and GDC were important intermediates in the field of fine chemistry. Despite that CO2 is considered as a greenhouse gas, it could be also utilized as a cheap and nontoxic carbon source to produce bio-products, solid materials, fuels, chemicals and materials [61]. Thus, all these compounds were reasonably considered as useful products. In view of these facts, the E-factor value for the production of GLC applying all the catalyst was 0, strongly suggesting that these catalytic samples had an ecofriendly and environmentally benign nature. Besides, process mass intensity is often chosen as an important parameter to assess the sustainability of the reaction, and mainly calculated according to the mass of all the materials (i.e., catalysts, solvents and reactants) in the reaction system [62,63]. Thereby, this factor is usually calculated by the following formula: (6) PMI = Total mass in the reaction system Mass of isolated product = Mass of catalysts + Mass of solvents + Mass of reactants Mass of target product Clearly, the lower value of PMI, the better sustainability of the reaction. In this work, the transesterification of DMC with glycerol was carried out without solvent no matter which catalyst was used. According to the catalytic results in Table 2, the mass of glycerol, DMC, catalyst as well as the target product of GLC could be obtained. Then, the values of PMI over various catalytic materials were determined using these data based on formula (6) (see Table 4). Apparently, it was easy to find that the lowest PMI value of 1.71 was achieved over Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F, which also exhibited the best catalytic performance in terms of GLC yield under the optimal reaction conditions. Similarly, another parameter of AU was applied to determine the percentage ratio of the desired product to mass of all products including desired and side products. Judging from this parameter, it is significantly convenient for study of the greenness of a reaction in light of co-generated waste [59]. Generally speaking, the solvents could be excluded for calculation of AU. Thus, the value of AU can be defined as: (7) Atom utiliazatin AU % = Mass of the desired product Total mass of all the substances products × 100 % During transesterification glycerol with DMC, the main by-product was methanol, which can be regarded as a solvent in chemical synthesis process. As a result, methanol can be ignored for the calculation of AU. Considering that only little amounts of GDC, CO2 and GD were co-created (see Scheme 1 and Fig. 7), the reaction process possessed a high value of AU (92.2%) catalyzed by the catalyst of Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F under the best reaction conditions above-mentioned (see Table 4). In spite of the higher values of AU obtained over other samples such as ZrO2, Al2O3, Al2O3-ZrO2-0 F and Al2O3-ZrO2-0.5 F, Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F was reasonably regarded as the best catalyst in this work, judging from its high reactivity, environmental and economic compatibility for the GLC manufacture. 6 Conclusion To clarify the function of acidic-basic pairs for the synthesis of GLC via DMC transesterification with glycerol, we have fabricated a cheap, practical, heterogeneous fluorinated Al2O3-ZrO2 catalyst system using Na3AlF6 as F source with a mesoporous structure. XRD, Raman and TEM characterization results suggested that incorporation of guest atoms into zirconia resulted in the transformation of m-ZrO2 to t-ZrO2. Furthermore, both Al and F species had entered into t-ZrO2 lattice to generate a solid solution structure, endowing the catalysts a high stability. Importantly, the acidic-basic properties of Al2O3-ZrO2-nF catalysts could be controlled by simple adjustment of F: Al atomic ratio. Combined NH3/CO2-TPD characterization and catalytic test results of all the examined catalysts, it was shown that the basic samples displayed a promoted activity than their acidic counterparts. Interestingly, Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F exhibited higher reactivity than that of Al2O3-ZrO2-2 F, which contained the highest basic density of these catalysts, indicating that the synergistic effect between acidic and basic sites could enhance the catalytic activity tremendously. Thanks to its suitable amounts of acidic and basic sites, Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F can realize the atom-efficient synthesis of GLC with 91.2% GLC yield using equimolar amount of DMC and glycerol for the first time. In addition, the overall investigation of green chemistry metrics suggested that the catalytic sample of Al2O3-ZrO2-1 F was economical as well as ecologically friendly in nature. Hereby, this work provides a practical and robust acid-basic bifunctional ZrO2-based catalytic system for the green and efficient synthesis of GLC via atom economic transesterification between DMC and glycerol. coredata.dc:description: A series of Al2O3-ZrO2-nF solid solution catalysts (n was the F: Al atomic ratios) with Al: Zr molar ratio of 0.2, was fabricated by addition of varied amounts of (AlF6)3- into the ZrO2 via a co-precipitation method. To our delight, the acidic-basic properties of Al2O3-ZrO2-nF can be tuned by the change of n. Then, the role of acidic-basic sites was investigated for the glycerol carbonate (GLC) production from glycerol and dimethyl carbonate (DMC). Despite that the more basic samples exhibited higher reactivities compared to that of the more acidic ones, the cooperative effect between the acidic-basic pairs can enhance the catalyst activity strongly. So, the catalyst with F/Al= 1.0 can realize the quantitative and selective transformation of glycerol to GLC applying DMC/glycerol of 1:1 ratio with a GLC yield of 91.2%, owing to its appropriate acidic-basic property. Furthermore, the uniform solid solution structure can prevent the generation of free Al or F species, assuring the catalytic material an excellent stability. More importantly, several green parameters including process mass intensity, environmental factor and atom utilization were calculated to confirm the environmental and economic compatibility of the GLC synthesis over the model catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: The atom-efficient production of glycerol carbonate via transesterification between dimethyl carbonate and glycerol over fluorinated Al2O3-ZrO2 solid solution catalysts with suitable acidic-basic property
